Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students deepen their understanding of functions by comparing representations of several functions relating the same pair of quantities. They analyze two or more graphs simultaneously, interpreting their relative features and their average rates of change in context.

Students also study comparative statements in function notation, such as \(A(x)=B(x)\), \(B(10)>A(10)\), and explain them in terms of changes in population, changes in the trends of phone ownership, and the popularity of different television shows.

Students pay close attention to the intersection of two graphs in this lesson. Earlier in their study, they learned that a solution to a system of linear equations in two variables is a point where the graphs of the equations in the system intersect. Here, students recognize equations of the form \(f(x)=g(x)\) to mean functions \(f\) and \(g\) having the same output value at the same input value. They see that a solution to such an equation is the \(x\)-coordinate of a point where the graphs of \(f\) and \(g\) intersect.

Making comparisons involves looking beyond individual pieces of information. To accurately relate the information from multiple representations requires careful and precise use of mathematical language and notation. Students continue reasoning abstractly and quantitatively as they use their analyses of representations of functions to draw conclusions about the quantities in situations.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Compare key features of graphs of functions and interpret them in context.
  • Find the solutions and meanings of \(f(x)=g(x)\) in terms of a situation and a graph.
  • Interpret statements about two or more functions written in function notation.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Compare the features of graphs of functions and explain what they mean in the situations represented.
  • Make sense of an equation of the form \(f(x)=g(x)\) in terms of a situation and a graph, and know how to find the solutions.
  • Explain statements about two or more functions when they are written in function notation.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A3(B) calculate the rate of change of a linear function represented tabularly, graphically, or algebraically in context of mathematical and real-world problems;

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 4.9.1: Analyzing Graphs and Statements in Function Notation
  • 4.9.2: Interpreting Graphs and Statements in Terms of a Situation
    • 4.9.2: Self Check
    • 4.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 4.9.3: Comparing Functions Represented in Separate Graphs
    • 4.9.3: Self Check
    • 4.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 4.9.4: Compare Graphs and Statements that Represent Functions without a Context
    • 4.9.4: Self Check
    • 4.9.4: Additional Resources
  • 4.9.5: Analyzing Functions Using Real-World Context

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 4.9.6: Practice.

Required Materials

None

Required Preparation

None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

  • function
  • value
  • equation
  • proportion
  • probability

New Vocabulary

  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their creativity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Sample, Then Specialize
  • Compound Interest

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Creativity from Character Lab.
